label: potential-unverified-cure
text: In Japan during the 1970s, there was a huge scandal when a company sold 'magnetic healing belts' claiming they could cure diabetes and high blood pressure. Thousands bought them before regulators shut it down.

label: potential-unverified-cure
text: My grandmother in Nigeria swears by this traditional healer who claims his root mixture can cure malaria, typhoid, and HIV. The whole village goes to him instead of the clinic.

label: potential-unsafe-medication-advice
text: Remember when that Australian naturopath claimed black salve could cure skin cancer? People ended up with massive holes in their faces. Horrific.

label: potential-unsafe-medication-advice
text: There's a clinic in Tijuana advertising 'coffee enemas' as a cure for colon cancer. They charge $50k for a two-week treatment program. Absolutely predatory.

label: potential-unsafe-medication-advice
text: In the 1800s, mercury was prescribed for syphilis. Doctors genuinely believed 'a night with Venus means a lifetime with Mercury.' Patients died from mercury poisoning.

label: potential-unsafe-medication-advice
text: Saw a TikTok from India where someone claims neem leaves boiled in water can cure tuberculosis. This is dangerous - TB needs antibiotics!

label: potential-unverified-cure
text: My cousin in Mexico City fell for a pyramid scheme selling 'oxygen water' that supposedly prevents Alzheimer's. He lost 10k pesos.

label: potential-unverified-cure
text: Victorian-era 'electric belts' were marketed as cures for impotence, kidney disease, and 'female hysteria.' Pure quackery.

label: potential-unsafe-medication-advice
text: There's a guy in the Philippines claiming coconut oil enemas cure Parkinson's disease. He's got thousands of followers. Terrifying.

label: potential-unverified-cure
text: Friend in South Africa told me about 'muti' markets selling animal parts as cures for stroke and epilepsy. Some endangered species are being killed for this.

label: potential-unverified-cure
text: Remember Theranos? Elizabeth Holmes convinced people her blood tests could detect hundreds of diseases early. Complete fraud. People died because of delayed real diagnoses.

label: potential-unsafe-medication-advice
text: Saw a WhatsApp forward claiming bitter melon juice cures kidney failure. My aunt shared it with her dialysis support group. Had to report it.

label: potential-unsafe-medication-advice
text: In Victorian England, 'Mrs. Winslow's Soothing Syrup' for teething babies contained morphine. Thousands of infants died before it was banned in 1910.

label: potential-unsafe-medication-advice
text: There's a wellness influencer in Dubai claiming frankincense oil can reverse multiple sclerosis. She's charging $200 for consultation calls.

label: potential-unsafe-medication-advice
text: In 18th century Europe, smallpox inoculation involved rubbing pus from infected people into cuts. It worked but was super risky - about 2% died from the procedure itself.

label: potential-unverified-cure
text: My friend in Kenya says there's a pastor who claims laying hands and prayer water can cure sickle cell disease. Families are abandoning their kids' medical care.

label: potential-unsafe-medication-advice
text: Ancient Roman physician Galen prescribed gladiator blood as a cure for epilepsy. Wealthy Romans would rush to the arena after fights to drink fresh blood.

label: potential-unverified-cure
text: There's a clinic in Thailand advertising stem cell injections for Alzheimer's, ALS, and spinal injuries. Charging $30k. No peer-reviewed evidence.

label: potential-unsafe-medication-advice
text: In 1950s USA, lobotomies were performed as a cure for depression, anxiety, and schizophrenia. 50,000 procedures done. Most patients were left permanently disabled.

label: potential-unsafe-medication-advice
text: Medieval 'plague doctors' prescribed bloodletting as a cure for the Black Death. It made patients weaker and more likely to die.

label: potential-unverified-cure
text: There's a Russian clinic selling 'placenta therapy' claiming it reverses aging and cures chronic fatigue syndrome. Zero scientific backing.

label: potential-unsafe-medication-advice
text: In Ayurvedic medicine, some practitioners prescribe heavy metals like lead and mercury for various ailments. Multiple cases of poisoning reported.

label: potential-unverified-cure
text: Friend in Vietnam says there's a huge market for rhino horn powder as a cure for fevers and hangovers. Driving rhinos to extinction for placebo.

label: potential-unsafe-medication-advice
text: 18th century 'patent medicines' like 'Dr. Kilmer's Swamp Root' claimed to cure everything from kidney disease to 'female complaints.' Mostly alcohol and opium.

label: potential-unverified-cure
text: There's a German 'biological medicine' practitioner claiming injections of diluted organ extracts can cure autoimmune diseases. Completely unproven.

label: potential-unsafe-medication-advice
text: In Ancient Egypt, crocodile dung was used as a contraceptive and cure for eye infections. Spoiler: it did neither and caused serious infections.

label: potential-unsafe-medication-advice
text: During the 1918 flu pandemic, some doctors recommended whiskey and aspirin in massive doses. The aspirin overdoses killed many patients.

label: potential-unverified-cure
text: There's a Brazilian YouTuber with 2M followers claiming veganism and meditation cured his friend's leukemia. His friend is in remission from chemo.

label: potential-unsafe-medication-advice
text: Medieval barber-surgeons used leeches to 'balance the humors' and cure everything from pneumonia to plague. Most patients died from blood loss or infection.

label: potential-unverified-cure
text: My coworker's mom in Morocco paid ‚Ç¨5000 for 'Quranic healing water' that supposedly cures infertility. She's been scammed twice now.

label: potential-unsafe-medication-advice
text: In 1960s Thalidomide was prescribed for morning sickness. 10,000 babies born with severe deformities. One of medicine's worst disasters.

label: potential-unsafe-medication-advice
text: There's a Polish naturopath selling 'urine therapy' claiming drinking your own urine prevents cancer and cures acne. It's gaining traction on Instagram.

label: potential-unverified-cure
text: Ancient Greeks used 'mithridatium' - a mixture of 65 ingredients including viper flesh - as a universal antidote to all poisons. Nero's physician invented it.

label: potential-unsafe-medication-advice
text: Friend in Singapore says TCM shops are selling tiger bone wine for arthritis. It's illegal but still happening underground.

label: potential-unverified-cure
text: 1800s 'snake oil salesmen' literally sold Chinese water snake oil for joint pain. The American version had no actual snake oil and was mostly mineral oil.

label: potential-unsafe-medication-advice
text: In some parts of India, 'holy ash' from temples is applied to wounds instead of antibiotics. Leads to serious infections.

label: potential-unsafe-medication-advice
text: 17th century European doctors prescribed tobacco smoke enemas to resuscitate drowning victims and cure cholera. Yes, literally blowing smoke up someone's ass.

label: potential-unverified-cure
text: Medieval 'unicorn horn' (actually narwhal tusk) was sold at 10x its weight in gold as a cure for poison, epilepsy, and plague.

label: potential-unverified-cure
text: Friend in Argentina told me about a clinic offering 'ozone therapy' for COVID-19, claiming 98% cure rate. Completely fraudulent.

label: potential-unsafe-medication-advice
text: Ancient Roman women used lead-based cosmetics and lead acetate as sweetener. Lead poisoning may have contributed to the fall of Rome.

label: potential-unsafe-medication-advice
text: 1950s tobacco companies had doctors in ads claiming smoking cures throat irritation and helps asthma. We know how that turned out.

label: potential-unverified-cure
text: Friend in Peru says shamans are selling ayahuasca ceremonies as cures for PTSD and addiction. Some legitimate research, but many are scammers.

label: potential-unsafe-medication-advice
text: Victorian 'electric shock therapy' was prescribed for everything from constipation to depression to 'hysteria' in women. Often caused seizures.
